title: How to Remove a Stuck Ring: 5 Effective Strategies

steps.title: Slip one end of the dental floss under the ring.
steps.content: Slip one end of the dental floss under the ring. If necessary use a needle to get the dental floss under the ring. [1] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Thin ribbon can also work for this. Warning: Tight string wraps can cause skin damage, and may only work for simpler cases. If unsuccessful, the finger may be sore, and the swelling may worsen. You're not the only wikiHow reader who's ever had a ring stuck on their finger! Check out more tips for removing the stuck ring in the "I have a ring stuck on my finger that won't come off" forum !

steps.title: Wrap the dental floss around your finger, up to your knuckle.
steps.content: Wrap the dental floss around your finger, up to your knuckle. Wind snuggly, but not so tightly that you cause pain or turn the finger blue. Unwind it if it's too tight. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Unwind the dental floss, beginning at the bottom of the finger.
steps.content: Unwind the dental floss, beginning at the bottom of the finger. As you unwind the dental floss from the bottom, your ring will move up your finger until you can get it off. [3] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source If this method doesn’t work, seek medical care as soon as possible.

steps.title: Use something slippery.
steps.content: Use something slippery. Plenty of "skin-safe" household items can be used as lubricants to get the ring off in one piece and with minimal damage to skin. Dish soap might be your best option. Window cleaners such as Windex often work well—just make sure they don’t have any harsh chemicals. If the skin is broken or cut, choose your lubricant wisely. Otherwise, try any of these, using a generous amount at least as far as the knuckle. [4] X Research source Petroleum jelly Soap and water Windex or other window cleaners (make sure its safe on skin, read the bottle first) Oil (cooking oil, baby oil, etc.)

steps.title: Move the ring around, getting some of the lubricant underneath.
steps.content: Move the ring around, getting some of the lubricant underneath. Turn the ring around the finger a time or two, and spray or rub more lubricant on as well. Gently pull the ring off the finger, working it back and forth and turning it as you go, as necessary. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Place ice on the ring and elevate your arm.
steps.content: Place ice on the ring and elevate your arm. Grab an ice pack or wrap a few ice cubes in a towel. After placing the ice pack over the ring, lift your arm over your head for 5-10 minutes. [6] X Research source If you still can't remove the ring, try elevating the arm above shoulder level for a few minutes.

steps.title: Wrap your finger tightly in plastic wrap.
steps.content: Wrap your finger tightly in plastic wrap. Loop the wrap around your finger several times so the bottom edge of the plastic wrap borders the stuck ring. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Lubricate the ring and the plastic wrap.
steps.content: Lubricate the ring and the plastic wrap. Apply something like butter, dish soap, or another greasy substance over the surface of both the ring and the plastic wrap. [8] X Research source Ideally, you should be able to twist your ring around at this point.

steps.title: Twist the ring downward to remove it.
steps.content: Twist the ring downward to remove it. Carefully twist your ring, using the lubricated wrap to help guide it down the length of your finger. With a little patience and elbow grease, you should be able to remove the stuck ring with plastic wrap. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Twist your ring while manipulating the skin near your knuckle.
steps.content: Twist your ring while manipulating the skin near your knuckle. Do your best to twist the ring, using the motion to guide the jewelry down your finger. As you twist, try to maneuver any pockets of skin above your ring (near your knuckle) so they’re below the ring instead—this may help give the ring some leverage as you remove it.

steps.title: Clean the area where the ring was and tend to any other injuries.
steps.content: Clean the area where the ring was and tend to any other injuries. Don't put the ring back on until it has been re-sized or the swelling has gone down.
